scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-341 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-341 is a star with 1 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.02 times its radius. It is located 3414.95 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 3.6 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-341 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-341 system


Kepler-341 b

Kepler-341 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-341 b is 1.759 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-341 b is 1.180 that of Earth. At 1.759 Earth masses, Kepler-341 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Kepler-341 c

Kepler-341 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-341 c is 3.530 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-341 c is 1.700 that of Earth. At 3.530 Earth masses, Kepler-341 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Kepler-341 d

Kepler-341 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.18 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-341 d is 4.070 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-341 d is 1.850 that of Earth. At 4.070 Earth masses, Kepler-341 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Kepler-341 e

Kepler-341 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.24 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-341 e is 4.611 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-341 e is 1.990 that of Earth. With a mass below 5 Earth masses, a density of 3.22, and a semi-major axis of 0.242 astronomical units, Kepler-341 e could, potentially, be an ocean world - a planet with no dry land.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-341, which contains 4 exoplanets and was discovered by the Kepler.
name: Kepler-341 - System With 4 Exoplanets
